key_points: CNN's Chris Cuomo's interviews with his brother, New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, are now seen unfavorably due to the governor's COVID-19 nursing home deaths scandal.
CNN has banned Chris Cuomo from interviewing or covering stories about his brother, a policy that was temporarily lifted in 2020.
The Cuomo brothers' interviews last spring were characterized by their lighthearted banter but are now criticized as inappropriate.
Critics argue that Chris Cuomo interviewing his brother created a conflict of interest, making it unlikely tough questions would be asked.
The Cuomo administration is accused of undercounting COVID-19 deaths of nursing home residents to avoid blame for policies.
New York's attorney general reported the administration's undercounting of deaths; the governor blames nursing home staff for virus spread.
An Andrew Cuomo aide admitted they withheld the true nursing home death toll out of fear it would be used against them by Trump's Justice Department.
CNN has covered the nursing home death scandal on programs other than Chris Cuomo's, with anchors openly inviting the governor to respond.
Jake Tapper criticized Governor Cuomo for a bad decision that may have cost lives and accused his administration of hiding data.
Chris Cuomo has defended his interviews with his brother as significant and entertaining but has followed CNN's policy to not cover related scandals.
spokespersons: Roy Gutterman (Media law professor, Syracuse University)
